repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
At the cost of more complicated/less regular reference counting
code.
    
Essentially,
    
1. temps created for indexing memoryview slice are
    not cleaned up after they are finished with in normal use -
    they are left until the end of the function and cleaned up once
    there.
2. temps created for indexing memoryviews with the same type and
    the same rhs entry are shared. The assumption is that they are
   will most likely end up pointed to the same thing when they are
   reused.
3. When memoryview slices (temps and regular variables) are reassigned
   it checks if the left-hand side and the right-hand side have
   the same underlying memoryview. If so (likely!) then it skips
   all reference counting.
    
This gets a 10x speed up for a toy example of
    
```
def f(double[:,:] x):
  for i in range(x.shape[0]):
    a = x[i,:]
```
    
so it's probably worthwhile to do something similar to this.

Closes #5507

comment_data.body: We should try to keep the order in the tuple consistent here to reduce the risk of accidental misordering. I think the original order matched the arguments in `allocate_temp()`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -871,28 +877,31 @@ def allocate_temp(self, type, manage_ref, static=False, reusable=True):
                 self.temp_counter += 1
                 result = "%s%d" % (Naming.codewriter_temp_prefix, self.temp_counter)
                 if result not in self.names_taken: break
-            self.temps_allocated.append((result, type, manage_ref, static))
+            self.temps_allocated.append((result, type, additional_hashing, manage_ref, static))
             if not reusable:
                 self.zombie_temps.add(result)
-        self.temps_used_type[result] = (type, manage_ref)
+        self.temps_used_type[result] = (type, manage_ref, additional_hashing)

comment_data.body: I'd just call this method `allocate_temp`. I don't really see a reason (nor a good way) to distinguish it from the method of code writers. In any case, given the more complex implementation further down, the name is really misleading because it's very specific about what it does but does more than that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -774,6 +776,10 @@ def calculate_result_code(self):
 #        #  Release temporaries used by LHS of an assignment.
 #        self.release_subexpr_temps(env)
 
+    def call_funcstate_allocate_temp(self, code, type):
+        # implemented so it can be overidden in special cases
+        return code.funcstate.allocate_temp(type, manage_ref=self.use_managed_ref)

comment_data.body:
Isn't there already an `unpack()` function somewhere? I strongly suggest not distributing the knowledge about "which nodes to unwrap" (and in which order) all over the place. If we ever add new wrapping nodes or change the way the nodes are wrapped, we'll almost certainly forget to update at least some places where they were previously unwrapped.

We could have a generic `ExprNode.unpacked_node()` method that returns `self` unless specially overridden by utility nodes. That would be nice because it would also work recursively, with multiply wrapped nodes. But maybe that's not something for right now. Could be done as part of the 3.1 cleanup.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5057,6 +5063,30 @@ def is_simple(self):
 
         return self.result_in_temp()
 
+    def call_funcstate_allocate_temp(self, code, type):
+        from .UtilNodes import ResultRefNode
+        # make the type distinct from the "normal" memoryview type
+
+        type = type.make_dont_clear_temps_type()
+        # unwrap result-refs to deal with the optimized
+        #  for x in memview:
+        # direct iteration. (It'd still work without this but
+        # it wouldn't preserve the "same temp for same entry" which
+        # should make the speed-up more reliable)
+        base = self.base
+        if isinstance(base, ResultRefNode):
+            base = base.expression
+        if isinstance(base, NoneCheckNode):
+            base = base.arg

comment_data.body: Is it really worth the complexity of passing the `locals()` here and doing dict string formatting? I'm pretty sure we do not do that anywhere else, and it's really just two simple variables.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -266,9 +281,18 @@ def generate_buffer_slice_code(self, code, indices, dst, dst_type, have_gil,
         """
         src = self.cname
 
+        # There's a decent chance that the source and destination memoryviews are the same
+        # in which case we can skip the reference counting for speed
+        code.putln("if (%(dst)s.memview != %(src)s.memview) {" % locals())
+        code.put_xdecref(dst, self.type, have_gil=have_gil)
         code.putln("%(dst)s.data = %(src)s.data;" % locals())
         code.putln("%(dst)s.memview = %(src)s.memview;" % locals())
         code.put_incref_memoryviewslice(dst, dst_type, have_gil=have_gil)
+        code.putln("} else {")
+        # just copy the data
+        code.putln("%(dst)s.data = %(src)s.data;" % locals())
+        code.putln("}")

comment_data.body: No - it's just a style copied from the surrounding code. But I'll replace it next iteration
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -266,9 +281,18 @@ def generate_buffer_slice_code(self, code, indices, dst, dst_type, have_gil,
         """
         src = self.cname
 
+        # There's a decent chance that the source and destination memoryviews are the same
+        # in which case we can skip the reference counting for speed
+        code.putln("if (%(dst)s.memview != %(src)s.memview) {" % locals())
+        code.put_xdecref(dst, self.type, have_gil=have_gil)
         code.putln("%(dst)s.data = %(src)s.data;" % locals())
         code.putln("%(dst)s.memview = %(src)s.memview;" % locals())
         code.put_incref_memoryviewslice(dst, dst_type, have_gil=have_gil)
+        code.putln("} else {")
+        # just copy the data
+        code.putln("%(dst)s.data = %(src)s.data;" % locals())
+        code.putln("}")

commit.message:
Try to optimize slicing memoryviews in loops

At the cost of more complicated/less regular reference counting
code.

Essentially,

1. temps created for indexing memoryview slice are
   not cleaned up after they are finished with in normal use -
   they are left until the end of the function and cleaned up once
   there.
2. temps created for indexing memoryviews with the same type and
   the same rhs entry are shared. The assumption is that they are
   will most likely end up pointed to the same thing when they are
   reused.
3. When memoryview slices (temps and regular variables) are reassigned
   it checks if the left-hand side and the right-hand side have
   the same underlying memoryview. If so (likely!) then it skips
   all reference counting.

This gets a 10x speed up for a toy example of

```
def f(double[:,:] x):
  for i in range(x.shape[0]):
    a = x[i,:]
```

so it's probably worthwhile to do something similar to this.
Better target the direct loop over memoryview
Skip the reference counting more generally

milestone.description: Remove support for Python 2 and Python < 3.8.

title: Try to optimize slicing memoryviews in loops
